posts.cooked:
Hi, I’m a new programmer on our FRC team. I’ve been tasked with creating a demo mode of sorts, where we can take our robot to events and display it, and allow people to drive it. The system is detailed on the images below: Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.35 PM 1920×791 81.8 KB Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.46 PM 1920×778 87.9 KB The control HID will allow one of our team members to enable the other controller by simply holding down LT or RT past a 20% threshold. I couldn’t really find a great way to integrate it in CommandBase, so I decided to use GenericHID to create a boolean that is set as true when the trigger is past the threshold. I created duplicates of all of our robot commands, and edited them to require a boolean supplier. I’m having difficulty with the actual implementation of GenericHID. The only method I found that allows us to include a threshold value is “axisGreaterThan”, which requires an input of an eventLoop object. I couldn’t find great documentation on how eventLoop works, and how to implement it within my code. Could someone give me some help? Perhaps a way to create an event loop which permanently runs, or a better logic system for the demo mode? I’ll include my RobotContainer code.

Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.35 PM 1920×791 81.8 KB

Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.35 PM 1920×791 81.8 KB

Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.46 PM 1920×778 87.9 KB

Screenshot 2024-05-28 at 4.13.46 PM 1920×778 87.9 KB

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

I couldn’t really find a great way to integrate it in CommandBase, so I decided to use GenericHID to create a boolean that is set as true when the trigger is past the threshold.

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.button, class: CommandXboxController

CommandXboxController relies on CommandBase as a framework, which doesn’t have a way of disabling a controller. Therefore, it doesn’t really work for our purposes. If you look in the code I posted, we are implementing CommandXboxController in general, we just can’t in this specific case.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We have had issues with CommandXboxController in the past, because it has bugs that cause loop scheduler overruns.  This is why we resorted to GenericHID.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

which doesn’t have a way of disabling a controller.

You could set up a second button loop that works for the second controller, and when you press a button on the first controller, it switches the button loop for the command scheduler to the second loop.
How exactly would that work? In terms of scheduling and unscheduling using command scheduler.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
w1zxrd:

which doesn’t have a way of disabling a controller

There are other things you could do for this though. You could just have your finger on the disable button (I would recommend this at all times) or you could use a usb on/off switch in between the controller and laptop.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
You would call

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command, class: CommandScheduler

with your secondEventLoop object, and when configuring bindings for the second controller, pass it in to the trigger methods in CommandXboxController

And when you want to switch I think you could just do

Just make sure you put the release trigger in the second event loop too

Disclaimer: I’ve never tried this. In theory it should work

Periodically calling CommandXboxController button functions causes CommandScheduler loop overruns opened 04:47AM - 10 Nov 23 UTC bhall-ctre type: bug component: command-based

Periodically calling CommandXboxController button functions causes CommandScheduler loop overruns opened 04:47AM - 10 Nov 23 UTC bhall-ctre type: bug component: command-based

opened 04:47AM - 10 Nov 23 UTC bhall-ctre

opened 04:47AM - 10 Nov 23 UTC

bhall-ctre

type: bug component: command-based

**Describe the bug**
If you have a `CommandXboxController` and periodically cal … l any of the button functions, such as `CommandXboxController::a`, you will eventually get CommandScheduler loop overruns. This is a regression from the 2023 season.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a `CommandXboxController m_controller`
2. In a periodic loop, call `m_controller.a();`
3. Wait for a couple minutes. Eventually you will see CommandScheduler loop overruns.

**Expected behavior**
This shouldn't cause CommandScheduler loop overruns, or it should be clearly documented that this can cause overruns and should be avoided (such as by caching the Trigger, or using `m_controller.getHID().getAButton()` instead). As it is, this scenario should be avoided anyways.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Project Information: WPILib 2024.1.1-beta-3

**Additional context**
`CommandXboxController::a` (and other buttons) calls the regular `XboxController::a`, which constructs a BooleanEvent, and casts the result to a Trigger. Because of the changes made in https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/5436, BooleanEvent now binds a Runnable to the EventLoop to update its state, so every call to `CommandXboxController::a` adds a Runnable to the EventLoop, eventually causing loop overruns.

The primary situation where I see teams would run into this is by calling `m_controller.a().getAsBoolean()` periodically to poll a button. This used to be safe (although a bad idea due to GC pressure), but now it can cause loop overruns.

Note this also affects the regular controller functions that return BooleanEvent.

**Describe the bug**
If you have a `CommandXboxController` and periodically cal … l any of the button functions, such as `CommandXboxController::a`, you will eventually get CommandScheduler loop overruns. This is a regression from the 2023 season.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a `CommandXboxController m_controller`
2. In a periodic loop, call `m_controller.a();`
3. Wait for a couple minutes. Eventually you will see CommandScheduler loop overruns.

**Expected behavior**
This shouldn't cause CommandScheduler loop overruns, or it should be clearly documented that this can cause overruns and should be avoided (such as by caching the Trigger, or using `m_controller.getHID().getAButton()` instead). As it is, this scenario should be avoided anyways.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Project Information: WPILib 2024.1.1-beta-3

**Additional context**
`CommandXboxController::a` (and other buttons) calls the regular `XboxController::a`, which constructs a BooleanEvent, and casts the result to a Trigger. Because of the changes made in https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/5436, BooleanEvent now binds a Runnable to the EventLoop to update its state, so every call to `CommandXboxController::a` adds a Runnable to the EventLoop, eventually causing loop overruns.

The primary situation where I see teams would run into this is by calling `m_controller.a().getAsBoolean()` periodically to poll a button. This used to be safe (although a bad idea due to GC pressure), but now it can cause loop overruns.

Note this also affects the regular controller functions that return BooleanEvent.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Yeah but that has such an easy fix that it’s not worth getting rid of CommandXboxController altogether, imo

A team member who was on a team last year and the year before (we’re a rookie team, the team member is the only one with any FRC experience) says that it’s stressful, and also this allows our control team member to put in some corrective actions if the robot is moving dangerously.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: I can speak from experience that this does work well. 341 has been running Sparky’s Robot World for something like 11 or 12 years now. We have a field with a couple quidditch looking goals, and small robots often controlled by children shooting foam balls into the goals. We always have 1 person stationed per controller with an on/off switch for the robot for safety reasons. It’s not that stressful, in fact it has prevented many collisions between erratically controlled robots and students resetting the field. As far as the corrective actions, with having a second controller, how would this work? Would inputs from the second controller only happen if the first one was disabled? I imagine the command scheduler would not be happy if you had 2 controllers controlling the same thing. read the other responses more in depth, nvm for the second part

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

We have had issues with CommandXboxController in the past, because it has bugs that cause loop scheduler overruns. This is why we resorted to GenericHID.

It’s more a possible footgun than a bug, and shouldn’t be something you encounter if you’re using the class the way it is intended.

For context: if you repeatedly call the trigger factories from periodic code, you will leak memory.  This should be fixed for 2025, but also there is no reason to ever do this in the first place.  If you need to poll the controller state imperatively, do it on the internal non-Command controller instance.
